SubTopics: Use evidence from a given landscape that includes simple landforms and rock layers to support a claim about the role of erosion or deposition in the formation of the landscape over long periods of time.
Content: The picture below shows a river flowing through a canyon.
problems/MA21G5S/media/1a.jpg
Which of the following best explains how the canyon becomes wider and deeper over time?

A.Choice: Water carries rock particles away from the canyon.

B.Choice: Caves form in the canyon walls and rock particles move into them.

C.Choice: Earthquakes cause the rocks of the canyon to move away from each other.

D.Choice: Volcanic activity causes the rocks on each side of the canyon to become larger.

SubTopics: Use informational text to provide examples of improvements to existing technologies (innovations) and the development of new technologies (inventions). Recognize that technology is any modification of the natural or designed world done to fulfill human needs or wants.
Content: A diagram of a tennis racket is shown.
problems/MA21G5S/media/2a.jpg
The design of tennis rackets has changed over time. Some changes to the design are shown in the table.
problems/MA21G5S/media/2b.jpg
Which of the following best explains the difference in weight of the tennis rackets?

A.Choice: Over time, tennis rackets have become lighter in weight because of a change in the racket head size.

B.Choice: Over time, tennis rackets have become heavier in weight because of a change in the racket head size.

C.Choice: Over time, tennis rackets have become lighter in weight because of a change in the racket frame material.

D.Choice: Over time, tennis rackets have become heavier in weight because of a change in the racket frame material.

SubTopics: Conduct an experiment to determine whether the mixing of two or more substances results in new substances with new properties (a chemical reaction) or not (a mixture).
Content: A group of students stirred sand into a beaker of water. The beaker was set on a table for 10 minutes. After 10 minutes, three layers formed in the beaker, as shown in the diagram.
problems/MA21G5S/media/3a.jpg
The students made these observations after 10 minutes:

:ibox:‚Ä¢ The top layer was mostly water with some sand particles in it.

‚Ä¢ The middle layer was mostly solid with small grains of sand.

‚Ä¢ The bottom layer was mostly solid with large grains of sand.

‚Ä¢ Each layer was at room temperature.
Some students claimed that a chemical reaction took place when the sand was stirred into the water. Other students claimed that a mixture was formed.
Which of the following is best supported by the students' observations?

A.Choice:
Claim: A chemical reaction took place.

Evidence: Three layers formed.

B.Choice:
Claim: A chemical reaction took place.

Evidence: The water had some sand particles in it.

C.Choice:
Claim: A mixture was formed.

Evidence: Each layer was at room temperature.

D.Choice:
Claim: A mixture was formed.

Evidence: The water and sand were mostly separated.

SubTopics: Use sketches or drawings to show how each part of a product or device relates to other parts in the product or device.
Content: A group of students designed a box to keep their lunches cool during recess. Their design is shown.
problems/MA21G5S/media/4a.jpg
Which of the following ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß describes the main purpose of the part labeled W in the design?

A.Choice: It keeps the box from falling over.

B.Choice: It gives support to the rest of the box.

C.Choice: It stops warm air from blowing on the box.

D.Choice: It blocks heat energy from entering the box.

SubTopics: Make observations and measurements of substances to describe characteristic properties of each, including color, hardness, reflectivity, electrical conductivity, thermal conductivity, response to magnetic forces, and solubility.
Content: A scientist tested four objects: W, X, Y, and Z. Two of the objects were made of the same substance, and the other objects were made of different substances. The scientist collected the data in the table.
problems/MA21G5S/media/5a.jpg
Identify the ùóßùó™ùó¢ objects that were made of the same substance. Explain your reasoning ùóîùó°ùóó include data from the table to support your answer.

A.Choice: Object W

B.Choice: Object X

C.Choice: Object Y

SubTopics: Define a simple design problem that reflects a need or a want. Include criteria for success and constraints on materials, time, or cost that a potential solution must meet.
Content: A software engineer designed a new version of a video game. The original version of the game and the new version are compared in the table.
problems/MA21G5S/media/6a.jpg
Select ùóßùóõùó•ùóòùóò design criteria the engineer most likely used in designing the new version of the game.

A.Choice: must cost more to make than the original version

B.Choice: must allow more players than the original version

C.Choice: must take longer to design than the original version

D.Choice: must have more levels of play than the original version

E.Choice: must have more levels of difficulty than the original version

SubTopics: Use a particle model of matter to explain common phenomena involving gases, and phase changes between gas and liquid and between liquid and solid.
Content: :ibox:ùóßùóõùóúùó¶ ùó§ùó®ùóòùó¶ùóßùóúùó¢ùó° ùóõùóîùó¶ ùóßùóõùó•ùóòùóò ùó£ùóîùó•ùóßùó¶.
The model shown represents particles of a substance in a closed container before and after a phase change.
problems/MA21G5S/media/7a.jpg
What state of matter was the substance before the phase change?

A.Choice: solid

B.Choice: liquid

C.Choice: gas

Content: What state of matter was the substance after the phase change?

A.Choice: solid

B.Choice: liquid

C.Choice: gas

Content: What type of phase change took place?

A.Choice: condensation

B.Choice: evaporation

C.Choice: freezing

SubTopics: Evaluate the merit of a design solution that reduces the damage caused by weather.
Content: Houses built in places that have hurricanes need to be protected from strong winds and flooding. The design shown helps keep winds from blowing the roof off a house during a hurricane.
problems/MA21G5S/media/8a.jpg
Which drawing represents the ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß way to modify the house so that it is also protected from flooding?

A.Choice: problems/MA21G5S/media/8b.jpg

B.Choice: problems/MA21G5S/media/8c.jpg

C.Choice: problems/MA21G5S/media/8d.jpg

Content: :ibox:ùóßùóõùóúùó¶ ùó§ùó®ùóòùó¶ùóßùóúùó¢ùó° ùóõùóîùó¶ ùóßùó™ùó¢ ùó£ùóîùó•ùóßùó¶.
When a tuning fork is hit, it vibrates and makes a sound. A picture of a tuning fork is shown.
problems/MA21G5S/media/9a.jpg
Which of the following happens when a tuning fork is hit?

A.Choice: The tuning fork creates sound waves that carry kinetic energy.

B.Choice: The tuning fork creates sound waves that carry electrical energy.

C.Choice: The tuning fork creates sound waves that carry magnetic energy.

Content: Which of the following would happen if a tuning fork is hit and then placed in water?

A.Choice: The sound waves will move the water.

B.Choice: The sound waves will immediately stop moving.

SubTopics: Ask testable questions about the process by which plants use air, water, and energy from sunlight to produce sugars and plant materials needed for growth and reproduction.
Content: The students also studied how pea plants use energy.
Which of the following best describes how pea plants use energy?

A.Choice: Pea plants use energy from soil to break down food.

B.Choice: Pea plants use energy from sunlight to break down food.

C.Choice: Pea plants use energy from water to make their own food.

D.Choice: Pea plants use energy from sunlight to make their own food.

SubTopics: Develop a model to describe the movement of matter among producers, consumers, decomposers, and the air, water, and soil in the environment to (a) show that plants produce sugars and plant materials, (b) show that animals can eat plants and/or other animals for food, and (c) show that some organisms, including fungi and bacteria, break down dead organisms and recycle some materials back to the air and soil.
Content: A student is classifying some organisms from the garden into these three groups: producer, consumer, and decomposer.
Which of the following tables correctly classifies each organism?

A.Choice: problems/MA21G5S/media/11a.jpg

B.Choice: problems/MA21G5S/media/11b.jpg

C.Choice: problems/MA21G5S/media/11c.jpg

SubTopics: Use a model to describe that the food animals digest (a) contains energy that was once energy from the Sun, and (b) provides energy and nutrients for life processes, including body repair, growth, motion, body warmth, and reproduction.
Content: A student noticed that the small aphids in the garden grew larger over time. Which of the following best describes what the aphids must have done to grow larger?

A.Choice: ate more of the plant for food

B.Choice: used more matter from the soil

C.Choice: absorbed more sunlight for food

D.Choice: received more energy from the air

SubTopics: Ask testable questions about the process by which plants use air, water, and energy from sunlight to produce sugars and plant materials needed for growth and reproduction.
Content: :ibox:ùóßùóõùóúùó¶ ùó§ùó®ùóòùó¶ùóßùóúùó¢ùó° ùóõùóîùó¶ ùóßùóõùó•ùóòùóò ùó£ùóîùó•ùóßùó¶.
A student is investigating the process of photosynthesis.
Identify the part of the pea and lettuce plants where most photosynthesis takes place.
What must the pea and lettuce plants take up through their roots to perform photosynthesis?
The student is also investigating the effect of sunlight on the total mass of the vegetables produced in the garden. The student graphs the data from box W and box Y, as shown.
problems/MA21G5S/media/13a.jpg
Explain why the student compared the data from boxes W and Y instead of the data from boxes W and Z to determine the effect of sunlight.

SubTopics: Analyze and interpret maps of Earth's mountain ranges, deep ocean trenches, volcanoes, and earthquake epicenters to describe patterns of these features and their locations relative to boundaries between continents and oceans.
Content: The Ring of Fire is a region around the Pacific Ocean that has many volcanoes. The area shaded gray on the map is where the Ring of Fire is located.
problems/MA21G5S/media/14a.jpg
Which of the following best explains why there are many volcanoes in this region?

A.Choice: There is an ocean in this region.

B.Choice: There are plate boundaries in this region.

C.Choice: There are only four continents in this region.

D.Choice: There is always a warm climate in this region.

SubTopics: Use a model to describe the cycling of water through a watershed through evaporation, precipitation, absorption, surface runoff, and condensation.
Content: :ibox:ùóßùóõùóúùó¶ ùó§ùó®ùóòùó¶ùóßùóúùó¢ùó° ùóõùóîùó¶ ùóßùóõùó•ùóòùóò ùó£ùóîùó•ùóßùó¶.
A student used a model to show how fresh water cycles in Massachusetts. The model is shown.
problems/MA21G5S/media/15a.jpg

In the model, the water represented a lake and the clay represented land. A lamp shined through the lid and onto the water. The student placed an ice pack on top of the clear lid. Water droplets formed under the ice pack and dripped onto the clay.
Identify what the lamp represented in this model.
Describe the part of the water cycle that was represented by the lamp shining on the water in the container. In your answer, be sure to describe what happened to the water.
Identify the part of the water cycle that was represented by the droplets of water forming on the bottom of the lid under the ice pack. Explain your reasoning.

SubTopics: Measure and graph the weights (masses) of substances before and after a reaction or phase change to provide evidence that regardless of the type of change that occurs when heating, cooling, or combining substances, the total weight (mass) of matter is conserved.
Content: A student adds liquid water to a measuring cup and freezes it. The surface of the ice that forms is above the 1-cup measurement line, as shown.
problems/MA21G5S/media/16a.jpg

The ice then melts and the student observes that the surface of the liquid water is below the 1-cup measurement line. The student claims the number of water particles in the ice and in the liquid water was the same.
To provide evidence for this claim, what did the student most likely do before and after the ice melted?

A.Choice: measured the level of the water using a ruler

B.Choice: measured the mass of the water using a scale

C.Choice: measured the temperature of the water using a thermometer

D.Choice: measured the circumference of the measuring cup using a tape measure

Content: :ibox:ùóßùóõùóúùó¶ ùó§ùó®ùóòùó¶ùóßùóúùó¢ùó° ùóõùóîùó¶ ùóßùó™ùó¢ ùó£ùóîùó•ùóßùó¶.

A teacher played a game with a class of students. During the game, the teacher gave hand signals. The students watched the teacher and then moved a game piece on a board based on the teacher's hand signals. The move required by each hand signal is shown.

:ibox:‚Ä¢ closed fist: move up one space

‚Ä¢ one thumb up: move down one space

‚Ä¢ two thumbs up: move left one space

‚Ä¢ open hand: move right one space
The teacher gave several hand signals and the students moved their game pieces.
Which of the following best describes how information was transferred as the teacher gave the hand signals?

A.Choice: The teacher encoded a message and then sent it to the students.

B.Choice: The teacher decoded a message and then sent it to the students.

C.Choice: The teacher decoded a message and then received it from the students.

D.Choice: The teacher encoded a message and then received it from the students.

Content: Which of the following best describes how information was transferred after the teacher gave the hand signals?

A.Choice: The students sent a message and then encoded it.

B.Choice: The students decoded a message and then sent it.

C.Choice: The students received a message and then decoded it.

D.Choice: The students encoded a message and then received it.

SubTopics: Compare at least two designs for a composter to determine which is most likely to encourage decomposition of materials.
Content: Students are testing two designs of a compost bin. One bin has gaps in its sides, while the other does not. Each design is shown.
problems/MA21G5S/media/18a.jpg
Each bin contains the same amount of materials that will be composted. One student claims that the gaps in design 1 will allow the materials to break down faster than in design 2.
Which of the following best supports the student's claim?

A.Choice: The gaps in design 1 allow air to flow into the bin.

B.Choice: The gaps in design 1 allow the materials to dry out.

C.Choice: The gaps in design 1 allow heat to escape from the bin.

D.Choice: The gaps in design 1 allow light to shine on the materials.

SubTopics: Use graphs and tables of local weather data to describe and predict typical weather during a particular season in an area.
Content: The table shows weather data collected over a three-day period.
problems/MA21G5S/media/19a.jpg
Which of the following ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß explains why there was a greater chance of precipitation on day 2 than on day 1?

A.Choice: Day 1 had stronger winds.

B.Choice: Day 2 had higher humidity.

C.Choice: Day 1 had colder temperatures.

D.Choice: Day 2 had more wind from the north.

SubTopics: Obtain and combine information about ways communities reduce human impact on the Earth's resources and environment by changing an agricultural, industrial, or community practice or process.
Content: The people in a town want to help the environment. Which of the following is one way the people in the town can reduce human impact on the environment?

A.Choice: heat town buildings using oil and propane gas

B.Choice: build a housing development in a forested area

C.Choice: install street lights throughout the town so people can see at night

D.Choice: build a water-treatment plant that cleans and recycles wastewater
